bad.work: For Children: The Gates of Paradise

title.reg: For Children: The Gates of Paradise

titlestmt.title: For Children: The Gates of Paradise Copy A : electronic edition
titlestmt.sponsor: The University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, the University of Rochester, and the Library of Congress

filedesc.extent: 1 XML file approx. 200KB; 36 JPEG (ISO/IEC 10918) files ranging in size from 500KB to 1800KB.
filedesc.publicationstmt: Chapel Hill: Eaves, Essick, Viscomi; UNC Libraries August 2024
filedesc.updatestmt:
The William Blake Archive is pleased to announce the publication of a digital edition of For Children: The Gates of Paradise Copy A, from the Rosenwald Collection, Library of Congress. In 1793, Blake etched and published For Children, an emblem book comprising eighteen small intaglio plates. Through a numbered series of designs with inscriptions ranging from single words to brief aphorisms, Blake puts the course of human life in psychological perspective. Some of the emblems form narrative sequences; others exemplify mental states and their reification in the external world. Though the first of five copies printed in 1793, Copy A is unique in that all of its 18 plates are in their first states, whereas the other copies printed in 1793, including Copy D, which is in the Archive, are in their second states.
Copy A is a proof copy, that is, it was printed to proof the designs and prepare them for the subsequent copies. It also joins For the Sexes: The Gates of Paradise Copies B, D, F, and K, already in the Archive. For the Sexes is the revised version of For Children, augmented with three new plates, 19, 20, and 21. Copy B was printed c. 1818 with all but one of its first 18 plates in their third state; Copy D was printed c. 1825 with all but two of its first 18 plates in their fourth state; Copy K was printed c. 1826–27 with nearly all the core plates in their fifth and final state; Copy F, with all plates in their final states, was one of four copies posthumously printed by Catherine Blake, c. 1828–29.
With this publication of For Children: The Gates of Paradise Copy A, combined with our earlier publications of Copy D of For Children and four copies of For the Sexes, the Archive now presents all known states of all the plates Blake used for both works. Thus, the Archive enables students of Blake, using our compare feature (Objects from the Same Matrix) located below the image, to trace the evolution of every design from its first and second states in 1793 through Blake’s revisions in c. 1818, 1825, and c. 1826-27. The original plate numbers etched lower left corner below the designs were erased and repositioned in the plate’s second state, which included an imprint, “Publishd by WBlake 17 May 1793” or a variant thereof, sometimes including the name of Blake’s London neighborhood, “Lambeth.” The second state of Plate 2, the title plate, reads “Published by W Blake No 13 Hercules Buildings Lambeth and J. Johnson St. Pauls' Church Yard.” In Copy A the title page is a proof that bears fragments of an erased imprint that may refer to J. Dodsley as the publisher or co-publisher. There is no other evidence that either Johnson (a bookseller for whom Blake executed many engravings) or Dodsley actually participated in the publication of the book. Johnson, however, may have been involved in selling, or at least displaying copies, of the book, for in a letter of 25 Sept. 1794 to Francis Douce, Richard Twiss states that “Blakes Paradise…. You will see” along with “several more of Blakes books” at “Johnsons” (Bentley, Records, page 65).
As always, the William Blake Archive is a free site, imposing no access restrictions and charging no subscription fees. The site is made possible by the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill with the University of Rochester, the continuing support of the Library of Congress, and the cooperation of the international array of libraries and museums that have generously given us permission to reproduce works from their collections in the Archive.

objtitle.title: For Children: The Gates of Paradise

objdescid.origination: William Blakeauthor, inventor, delineator, etcher, printer

imprint.publisher: William Blake and Joseph Johnson There is no imprint in the first state impression of Object 2, the title page, in Copy A. Johnson's name appears in the imprint on Object 2, the title page, in its second state, but the extent of his involvement in the publication of the work is not known. He may have been involved in the selling, or at least displaying copies, of the book, for in a letter of 25 Sept. 1794 to Francis Douce, Richard Twiss states that “Blakes Paradise…. You will see” along with “several more of Blakes books” at “Johnsons” (Bentley, *Records*, page 65).
imprint.pubplace: Lambeth The London suburb of "Lambeth" is recorded as the place of publication on Objects 2, 6, 9, 10, 13, 14, 16, and 17 in their second states. Object 2, the title page, in its second state also gives Joseph Johnson's London address.
imprint.date: 1793The date does not appear in Copy A but was added to Object 2, the title page, in its second state. The imprints on other plates in their second states include the date "17 May 1793". There is no imprint on Object 15 (Bentley Plate 15) in its second state.

objdescid.compdate: 1793The work is based on designs Blake drew in his Notebook; some of these sketches may have been executed c. 1790-92.

objinfo.objorder: Bentley Plates 1-18 Object 1, the frontispiece, is bound facing Object 2, the title page.
objinfo.objsize: Platemarks range in size between 9.4 x 7.4 cm. and 6.1 x 4.2 cm.
objinfo.medium: intaglio etching/engravingAll plates are in their first state. Copy A can be considered a proof or pre-publication copy because of the absence of the imprints added to all but Object 15 (Bentley Plate 15) in their second states. There are five states of Objects 1-10, 13-18 (Bentley Plates 1-10, 13-18), three states of Object 11 (Bentley Plate 11), and four states of Object 12 (Bentley Plate 12). The first two states appear in copies of *For Children: The Gates of Paradise* and states three through five in copies of *For the Sexes: The Gates of Paradise*. The only recorded copy with the plates in their first states is Copy A of *For Children*. See Bentley pages 187-91 for brief descriptions of the differences between the first and second states. Blake added three plates, Bentley Plates 19-21, when he transformed *For Children* into *For the Sexes* c. 1818.
objinfo.watermark: MAFRINSThis (probably fragmentary) watermark appears only on Objects 13 and 15. Bentley page 186, note 2, states that the watermark is "almost illegible" and that Object 2, the title page, in Copy A is "on clearly different paper" from the other objects.
objinfo.etchednumbers: 1 lower left on Object 1; 2-16 lower left on Objects 4-18
objinfo.binding: red moroccoBentley page 191 notes that the binding probably dates from c. 1805.
objinfo.stabholes: Originally stabbed through three holes, 3.2 cm. from the top edge of the leaves and 3.9 cm. and 3.8 cm. apart.

provenance.name: Library of Congress
provenance.note: Acquired by Rebekah Bliss, probably directly from Blake no later than c. 1805; sold from her collection, Saunders and Hodgson auction, London, 26 April 1826, lot 10 (8s.); P. A. Hanrott, sold from his collection, Evans auction, London, 26 April 1833, lot 894 (£1.16s. to "Thorpe," probably a dealer possibly acting for "Clarke," also probably a dealer); William Beckford, sold from his collection Sotheby's, 4 July 1882, lot 953 (£16 to the dealer James Bain); acquired by Bernard Buchanan Macgeorge, possibly at the 1882 Beckford auction but no later than 1892; sold from the Macgeorge collection, Sotheby's, 1 July 1924, lot 112 (£174 to the dealer Maggs Bros.); offered by Maggs, 1924 catalogue 456, item 55 (£275); W. E. Moss by no later than 1927; sold from his collection, Sotheby's, 2 March 1937, lot 176 (£460 to the dealer A. S. W. Rosenbach, probably acting for Lessing J. Rosenwald); given by Rosenwald to the Library of Congress in 1945.

illustration.illusobjdesc: We see two large leaves, perhaps oak leaves, growing from a branch. The veins on the lower leaf are particularly prominent. The upper leaf bears a large caterpillar which may be eating the edge of the leaf. The lower leaf cradles an infant or at least the head of an infant with closed eyes whose body suggests both swaddling bands and a chrysalis. There are slight indications of curly hair on the infant's head.

component.illusobjdesc: We see two large leaves, perhaps oak leaves, growing from a branch. The veins on the lower leaf are particularly prominent.
A large caterpillar rests on the edge of, and may be eating, a leaf.
A leaf cradles an infant—or at least the head of an infant with closed eyes—whose body suggests both swaddling bands and a chrysalis. There are slight indications of curly hair on the infant's head.

desc.objtitle: For Children The Gates of Paradise, Object 2 (Bentley 2, Erdman ii, Keynes ii)

objnote.p: The abraded condition of the paper below "Paradise" and above the ruled line, as well as the ghostly and fragmentary printing of an inscription beginning with the letter "P" and ending with the letters "ey", indicate that text was erased from this impression. The inscription must have also been removed from the copperplate because no such inscription appears in the next (second) state of the plate. Bentley, *Writings*, volume 1, page 165, suggests that the deleted inscription might be a reference to the publisher James Dodsley: “P[ublishd by J. Dodsl]ey.” There is, however, no other evidence that Dodsley was involved in the publication or sale of *For Children*.

illustration.illusobjdesc: A figure hovers in the air with arms extended horizontally. We apparently see this figure from behind, at least in part. The figure may be facing right. A few lines near the feet and legs suggest the hem of a gown.

component.illusobjdesc: A figure hovers in the air with arms extended horizontally. We apparently see this figure from behind, at least in part. The figure may be facing right. A few lines near the feet and legs suggest the hem of a gown.

objnote.p: A few very light lines lower left look like the number 17, but we suspect that these are just accidental scratches on the copperplate.

illustration.illusobjdesc: A large tree grows up the left margin, with branches arching toward the left in the top third of the image. Its long, dangling branches and/or leaves suggest it may be a willow. A few small plants with large leaves cover the ground below the trunk. To the right, below the tree's largest branch, is a gowned woman striding to the left with legs spread apart. Her hair is drawn into a bun on the back of her head. Her left arm is bent at the elbow and she holds in her left hand two small children or infants. We see only one child's head and the right eye and cheek of the other; a part of the woman's gown, or a separate blanket, covers the children's bodies. The woman, perhaps the children's mother or a nurse, leans over and faces down. She reaches down with her right arm and hand and appears to be pulling a third child or infant out of the earth. We see this child only from the chest up; his or her hair stands on end. The position of the child suggests that it is the anthropomorphic form of a vegetable, perhaps a mandrake, traditionally thought to be shaped like a human body. Perhaps the woman has "harvested" the other two children, held in her left arm, in a similar fashion. A few clouds fill the sky behind the tree's limbs and leaves.

component.illusobjdesc: A large tree grows up the left margin, with branches arching toward the left in the top third of the image. Its long, dangling branches and/or leaves suggest it may be a willow.
A few small plants with large leaves cover the ground below the trunk of the tree.
A few clouds fill the sky behind the tree's limbs and leaves.

A gowned woman strides to the left with legs spread apart. Her hair is drawn into a bun on the back of her head. Her left arm is bent at the elbow and she holds in her left hand two small children or infants. The woman, perhaps the children's mother or a nurse, leans over and faces down. She reaches down with her right arm and hand and appears to be pulling a third child or infant out of the earth. The fingers of her right hand are spread over the child's forehead.

The woman holds two small children or infants in her left arm and hand. We see only the head of one child, facing forward; the second child, above and two the right of the more prominent one, is indicated only by the left eye and cheek, facing up. The bodies of both children are covered with a portion of the woman's gown or a separate blanket.

The woman reaches down with her right arm and hand and appears to be pulling a child or infant out of the earth. We see this child only from the chest up; his or her hair stands on end. The position of the child suggests that it is the anthropomorphic form of a plant—perhaps a mandrake, traditionally thought to be shaped like a human body. Perhaps the woman has "harvested" the other two children, held in her left arm, in a similar fashion.

lg.l: I found him beneath a Tree

illustration.illusobjdesc: A nude male, apparently with long hair, sits on the bank of a river or lake with legs crossed at the ankles. He faces down, with eyes closed or partly closed. His arms reach down, and his hands rest on his knees; his palms are open and facing down with fingers spread. The lines on his face and his general expression suggest despair or melancholy. To the right is a tree, the barren branches of which arch over the figure. A few lines beneath its trunk may be roots. Other lines, almost vertical but slightly angled from right to left, cover most of the image and very probably represent rain. A river or lake appears lower left and below the man's feet. As the caption (line 1) indicates, "Water" is the subject, both literal and metaphoric, of the design.

component.illusobjdesc: A nude male, apparently with long hair, sits on the bank of a river or lake with legs crossed at the ankles. He faces down, with eyes closed or partly closed. His arms reach down, and his hands rest on his knees; his palms are open and facing down with fingers spread. His mouth is slightly open. The lines on his face and his general expression suggest despair or melancholy. He may be a personification of water as both a substance and a psychological state within a Blakean version of humoral theory.
A leafless tree grows up the right margin of the design, with a prominent limb arching over the seated man. Lines below the trunk of the tree suggest roots.

The man sits on a bank of earth above a river or lake. This body of water would seem to extend around the left end of the bank, thus making it a diminutive peninsula. Lines, almost vertical but angling slightly to the lower left, indicate heavy rain.

illustration.illusobjdesc: A nude male struggles within a cleft or cavern formed by dark and massive stones. He is bearded; his hair is slightly curly. He squats or crouches, with legs spread apart. His left leg is bent sharply at the knee and the right, slightly bent, is extended toward the lower margin of the image. He faces forward, with his arms raised, elbows bent. His hands are above his head; he may be grasping the top of his head with his left hand. The general expression is one of conflict, grief, and pain. He may be a personification of "Earth" (line 1) within a Blakean version of humoral theory.

component.illusobjdesc: A man struggles within a cleft or cavern formed by dark and massive stones.

A nude male struggles within a cleft or cavern formed by dark and massive stones. He is bearded; his hair is slightly curly. He squats or crouches, with legs spread apart. His left leg is bent sharply at the knee and the right, slightly bent, is extended toward the lower margin of the image. He faces forward, with his arms raised, elbows bent. His hands are above his head; he may be grasping the top of his head with his left hand. The general expression is one of conflict, grief, and pain. He may be a personification of "Earth" (line 1) within a Blakean version of humoral theory.

illustration.illusobjdesc: A youthful, nude male sits, in a crouch-like posture, on a cloud. Parts of this cloud, or perhaps other clouds, extend behind him and in front of him, covering his feet. Fourteen stars fill the night sky. His legs are bent sharply at his prominent knees. His hair is curly. His arms are bent at the elbows and extended upward, with both hands clasped over, and perhaps clutching, his forehead. His chin rests on his right knee. He faces forward, with a lined visage suggesting despair or melancholy. Given the caption, he may be a personification of "air" (line 1) within a Blakean version of humoral theory.

component.illusobjdesc: Clouds and fourteen stars fill the night sky.

A youthful, nude male sits, in a crouch-like posture, on a cloud. His legs are bent sharply at his prominent knees. His hair is curly. His arms are bent at the elbows and extended upward, with both hands clasped over, and perhaps clutching, his forehead. His chin rests on his right knee. He faces forward, with a lined visage suggesting despair or melancholy. Given the caption, he may be a personification of "air" (line 1) within a Blakean version of humoral theory.

illustration.illusobjdesc: A young and muscular nude male, with curly (almost snake-like) hair, stands facing forward. His legs are spread apart, and his arms are raised at approximately 135 degrees. His right arm is slightly bent. He holds a spear in his right hand; a large shield is buckled to his left arm and hand. His posture suggests triumph or challenge, but his visage expresses fear or pain. His mouth is slightly open, and his eyes are raised. Flames fill the background of the design and rise over the figure's right lower leg. The figure and his setting suggest both Blake's Orc (frequently associated with fire) and Milton's Satan in hell. The caption (line 1) indicates that he is, at the very least, a personification of "Fire."

component.illusobjdesc: Flames fill the background and foreground of the design. There may be smoke on each side of the figure's head. The fire and the character of the figure suggest this may be a vision of hell.

A young and muscular nude male, with curly (almost snake-like) hair, stands facing forward. His legs are spread apart, and his arms raised at approximately 135 degrees. His right arm is slightly bent. He holds a spear in his right hand; a large shield is buckled to his left arm and hand. His posture suggests triumph or challenge, but his lined visage expresses fear or pain. His mouth is slightly open, and his eyes are raised. The figure and his fiery setting suggest both Blake's Orc (frequently associated with fire) and Milton's Satan in hell. The caption (line 1) indicates that he is, at the very least, a personification of "Fire."

illustration.illusobjdesc: An infant or young child, nude and probably male, emerges like a hatchling from a broken egg. Given his wings, he may be a putto, cherub, or angel. His legs are crossed at the ankles; his left arm is bent, with his left hand placed on the shell as though he were pushing against it to rise. He faces forward, with his head up and eyes raised. His hair is curly. Clouds fill the sky behind the figure and the egg; two broken pieces of the latter rest in the foreground.

component.illusobjdesc: A child emerges from a broken egg, two pieces of which lie in the foreground. Clouds fill the sky.

An infant or young child, nude and probably male, emerges like a hatchling from a broken egg. Given his wings, he may be a putto, cherub, or angel. His legs are crossed at the ankles; his left arm is bent, with his left hand placed on the shell as though he were pushing against it to rise. He faces forward, with his head up and eyes raised. His hair is curly.

illustration.illusobjdesc: A young male strides, with legs spread, from left to right. He wears tights or a combination of breeches and a shirt. His hair is curly. He faces to the right, with a look of surprise or excitement on his face. His left arm is at his side; his right arm is raised vertically but slightly bent at the elbow. He holds a hat in his raised right hand. To the right of his face is a (nude and male?) human figure, perhaps an infant or child, hovering (flying?) in mid-air. We see this figure, also with curly hair, from the back, but facing to the left (toward the large figure). His legs are spread, as though fleeing from the youth with a hat, who may be pursuing him. The hovering figure has his arms extended horizontally. Below, on the ground and in the lower right corner of the design, is a second diminutive figure of uncertain gender. He or she may be dead and lies face-down, with the right leg extended and arms extended horizontally in a cruciform position. His or her hair is long. Given the positioning of these two small figures and the iconographic tradition from which this design may have been developed, the two small human forms may be personifications of birds or butterflies. The middle distance is dominated by leafy plants or trees. Clouds fill the sky in the upper portions of the design.

component.illusobjdesc: Clouds fill the sky in the upper portions of the design.
Leafy plants or trees fill the middle distance of the design.

A young male strides, with legs spread, from left to right. He wears tights—or a combination of breeches and a shirt. He may also wear shoes. His hair is curly. He faces to the right, with a look of surprise or excitement on his face. His left arm is at his side; his right arm is raised vertically but slightly bent at the elbow. He holds a hat in his raised right hand. He may be pursuing, and attempting to kill or capture, the flying figure to the right.

To the right of the large figure's face is a (nude and male?) human figure, perhaps an infant or child, hovering (flying?) in mid-air. We see this figure with curly hair from the back, but facing to the left (toward the large figure). His legs are spread, as though fleeing from the youth with a hat, who may be pursuing him. The hovering figure has his arms extended horizontally. Given the iconographic tradition from which this design may have been developed, this figure may be the anthropomorphic form of a bird or butterfly.

A diminutive figure of uncertain gender lies on the ground, lower right. He or she may be dead and lies face-down, with the right leg extended and arms extended horizontally in a cruciform position. His or her hair is long. Given the positioning of the two small figures and the iconographic tradition from which this design may have been developed, the two small human forms may be personifications of birds or butterflies.

illustration.illusobjdesc: On the left, a youthful male with curly hair strides to the left. Although basically pictured as a nude, a small piece of drapery seems to extend to the right of his left thigh. His body is twisted, and he faces to the right, toward a bearded man. The youth's right arm is raised horizontally, and he may be pointing toward this older man. His left arm is raised vertically; he grasps a spear or dart in his raised left hand. He may be about to throw his weapon at the old man. To the right sits a nude old man with long hair and a long beard. His left leg is bent at the knee, his right extended to the left. His left arm is bent at the elbow, and he props his head on his left hand, a posture traditionally indicative of melancholy. His body is twisted, and he looks down and to the right. His right arm is raised horizontally, and he grasps a large sword in his right hand. The positioning of the two figures and their relative ages suggest that the youth is an Orc-like figure and the old man is his father, as well as a king or Urizen figure. The caption (line 1), if spoken by the old man, indicates that the youth is his child. The old man's chair (a primitive throne?) is constructed of large stones. The back of the chair is also constructed of stones. Alternatively, if the perspective is distorted, this may be a ruined wall and the "chair" part of the wall or building. A large tree with several leafy branches arches above the old man. We see a low hill, a mountain behind and to the right, and clouds in the sky on the left. The earth in the foreground may be covered with grass.

component.illusobjdesc: A youthful male with curly hair strides to the left. Although basically pictured as a nude, a small piece of drapery seems to extend to the right of his left thigh. His body is twisted and he faces to the right, toward an old, bearded man. The youth's right arm is raised horizontally, and he may be pointing toward the bearded man. His left arm is raised vertically; he grasps a spear or dart in his raised left hand. He may be about to throw his weapon at the old man. The relative positions and ages of the figures suggest that the youth is an Orc figure. If the caption (line 1) is spoken by the old man, then the youth is his child.

To the right of the young man sits a nude old man with long hair and a long beard. His left leg is bent at the knee, his right extended to the left. His left arm is bent at the elbow, and he props his head on his left hand—a posture traditionally indicative of melancholy. His body is twisted, and he looks down and to the right. His right arm is raised horizontally, and he grasps a large sword in his right hand. The positioning of the two figures and their relative ages suggest that the youth is an Orc- like figure and the old man is his father, as well as a king or Urizen figure
The earth in the foreground of the design may be covered with grass.
A large tree with several leafy branches arches through the upper part of the design.

The bearded old man sits on a chair composed of large cut stones. The high back of the chair is also stony. Alternatively, if the perspective is distorted, this may be a ruined wall and the man's "chair" simply more stones from the wall or building.
A low hill fills the middle distance, with a mountain behind and to the right. Clouds fill the sky above.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The design is dominated by the night sky, complete with seven stars and a thin, crescent moon. A long ladder reaches from the surface of the earth, lower right, to the moon. A small figure has just begun to climb the ladder, with the left leg bent at the knee so as to place the left foot on the third rung of the ladder, and the right foot still on the earth. This figure's arms are raised horizontally, with his hands apparently holding the vertical sides of the ladder. The figure is probably male: he wears a hat and may be looking to the right. In the far right corner is a group of two figures, probably a woman on the left (wearing a dress or skirt) and a man on the right. The man has at least his left arm raised horizontally; he may be embracing the woman around her waist. The woman's right arm is bent at the elbow, with her forearm raised horizontally. Both these figures appear to be facing to the left and looking at the man climbing the ladder; the woman may be pointing at him.

component.illusobjdesc: The night sky shows seven stars. A ladder extends from the earth, lower right, to a crescent moon, top left.
A crescent moon appears in the night sky, top left.

A small figure has just begun to climb the ladder, with the left leg bent at the knee so as to place the left foot on the third rung of the ladder, and the right foot still on the earth. This figure's arms are raised horizontally, with his hands apparently holding the vertical sides of the ladder. The figure is probably male: he wears a hat and may be looking to the right.

In the far right corner of the image is a group of two figures, probably a woman on the left (wearing a dress or skirt) and a man on the right. The man has at least his left arm raised horizontally; he may be embracing the woman around her waist. The woman's right arm is bent at the elbow, with her forearm raised horizontally. Both these figures appear to be facing to the left and looking at the man climbing the ladder; the woman may be pointing at him.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The design is dominated by a stormy sky and sea, the former filled with clouds and the latter fraught with two large waves. Near one wave crest we see a human arm raised vertically, fingers spread apart. This figure's head (just to the left of the arm) is bent back and facing up. The figure is probably male and, given the caption, trying to swim but drowning in the attempt. He may be looking to the heavens for help but is in despair.

component.illusobjdesc: The design is dominated by a stormy sky and sea, the former filled with clouds and the latter fraught with two large waves.

Near one wave crest we see a human arm raised vertically, fingers spread apart. This figure's head (just to the left of the arm) is bent back and facing up. The figure is probably male and, given the caption, trying to swim but drowning in the attempt. He may be looking to the heavens for help but is in despair.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The design is based on a traditional emblem of Age clipping the wings of Love. On the left sits a gowned old man wearing spectacles (an indication of limited vision). He has a long beard and probably long hair. His eyes are closed or looking down; he may be blind or almost blind. His legs, with prominent knees, are crossed at the ankles. His left arm is raised horizontally, with the left hand grasping the wing of the youthful figure to the right. His right arm is bent at the elbow; he holds in his right hand a pair of scissors with which he is about to cut the tip of the youth's right wing. This winged and youthful male figure, nude and striding energetically to the right, is a winged Cupid, cherub, or angel. His legs are spread apart, as though running to the right; he may be fleeing from the old man. The youth's hair is curly. His right arm is bent upward at the elbow, with the fingers of his raised right hand spread apart. His body faces to the right, but we see only the back of his head as he looks back to the sun rising or setting on the distant horizon. Lines of radiance emanate from the sun. A tree, its branches arching over both figures, grows up the left margin. The leaves of a tree or large plant fill the background above the old man. There may be grass on the slight hill or mound on which the two figures are placed.

component.illusobjdesc: On the left sits a gowned old man wearing spectacles (an indication of limited vision). He has a long bear and probably long hair. His eyes are closed or looking down; he may be blind are almost blind. His legs, with prominent knees, are crossed at the ankles. His left arm is raised horizontally, with the left hand grasping the wing of the youthful figure to the right. His right arm is bent at the elbow; he holds in his right hand a pair of scissors with which he is about to cut the tip of the youth's right wing.

A winged and youthful male figure, nude and striding energetically to the right, is a winged Cupid, cherub, or angel. His legs are spread apart, as though running to the right; he may be fleeing from the old man. The youth's hair is curly. His right arm is bent upward at the elbow, with the fingers of his raised right hand spread apart. His body faces to the right, but we see only the back of his head as he looks back to the sun rising or setting on the distant horizon.
We see about half the sun rising or setting. Radiant beams of light emanate from it.

A tree, its branches arching over both figures, grows up the left margin. The leaves of a tree or large plant fill the background above the old man. There may be grass on the slight hill or mound on which the two figures are placed.

l.note: The number “11” is only faintly visible.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Within a small room, probably a prison cell built of stone, we see five seated male figures, all apparently nude (with the possible exceptions of the figures lower left and right). The central figure, facing forward, is old and bearded with hair standing on end; the others are much younger. This central figure has his legs drawn up; his knees are very prominent. His face suggests despair or worse. Immediately to the left, very close to the old man, is a young man with legs drawn up and crossed at the ankles. His knees are also prominent. His body faces forward, but his head is turned up and to the right; he may be looking at the face of the old man. Although we see only his right shoulder and upper arm, his right arm may be extended horizontally; he may be embracing the old man. On the right is another young male close to the old man. His legs are drawn up and crossed at the ankles, with prominent knees. His body faces forward, but his head is turned to the left, with his face pressed against the body or left leg of the old man. This figure's hair seems to be long. Another youthful male sits in the right foreground. His legs are extended but slightly bent at the knees. Although probably nude, like his companions, lines just below his knees suggest that he might be wearing breeches. His left arm is at his side, with his left hand on the ground (or, rather, on the floor), fingers spread apart. He faces left, with his head bent back and looking up; his mouth is slightly open. His hair is probably long. In the left foreground is the final youthful figure, seated and with legs extended. Though he may be nude, lines just below his knees suggest that he, too, may be wearing breeches. He faces to the right, with his head down. His right arm is at is side, with his right hand on the ground (or, rather, on the floor), fingers spread. His hair is curly. Given the configuration of the males, the setting, and the compositional relationship to several drawings by Blake, this design would seem to be inspired by Dante's description of Count Ugolino and his sons in prison.

component.illusobjdesc: Within a small room, probably a prison cell built of stone, we see five seated figures.

Within a small room, probably a prison cell built of stone, we see five seated male figures, all apparently nude (with the possible exception of the figures lower left and right, who may wear breeches). Given the configuration of these figures, the setting, and the compositional relationship to several drawings by Blake, this design would seem to be inspired by Dante's description of Count Ugolino and his sons in prison. All appear to be dying in pain and despair.

The central seated figure, male and apparently nude, in this group of five faces forward. He is old and bearded with hair standing on end. He has his legs drawn up; his knees are very prominent. His face suggests despair or worse. He may be Ugolino.

A youthful male nude sits next to the old man in the center of the design. His hair is long and perhaps drawn into a bun. His legs are drawn up and crossed at the ankles. His knees are prominent. His body faces forward, but his head is turned up and to the right; he may be looking at the face of the old man. Although we see only his right shoulder and upper arm, his right arm may be extended horizontally; he may be embracing the old man.

A youthful male nude sits next to the old man in the center of the design. His legs are drawn up and crossed at the ankles, with prominent knees. His body faces forward, but his head is turned to the left, with his face pressed against the body or left leg of the old man. This figure's hair seems to be long.

A youthful male sits in the lower right corner of the cell. He is probably nude, but lines just below his knees suggest that he may be wearing breeches. His legs are extended but slightly bent at the knees. His left arm is at his side, with his left hand on the ground (or, rather, on the floor), fingers spread apart. He faces left, with his head bent back and looking up; his mouth is slightly open. His hair is probably long.

A youthful male sits in the lower left corner of the cell. He is probably nude, but lines just below his knees suggest that he may be wearing breeches. He faces to the right, with his head down. His right arm is at is side, with his right hand on the ground (or, rather, on the floor), fingers spread. His hair is curly.

lg.l: Does thy God O Priest take such vengeance

illustration.illusobjdesc: We see the corner of a featureless chamber or cell, perhaps with stone walls and a wooden floor. The only furniture is a bed (or possibly a bier), probably made of wood. A body very probably dead lies supine and rigid on the bed, legs together and at least the right arm at his side. The fingers of his right hand are long and prominent. This gowned figure is very probably an old man, as indicated by his long beard. His face is hidden by another figure. At his feet, rising into the air at a 45 degree angle from lower right to upper left, is another gowned and bearded old man. We can see the supine figure's feet through the lower leg of the rising figure, and thus he is almost certainly the ghost or spirit of the dead man. His hair is long and he faces to the left. His right arm is bent at the elbow with the forearm raised horizontally across his body. The index finger of his right hand is extended and points to the right. His left arm is bent at the elbow with the forearm raised vertically. One finger of his left hand points upward. In the foreground on the left is a young man with curly hair. He squats or sits on his left leg, bent under his body; his right leg is extended to the right and bent slightly at the knee. He may be wearing tights, or at least a belt around his waist. His right arm is at his side, with the fingers of his right hand spread apart. His mouth is slightly open, and he appears to be looking up and to the right in fear or surprise at the ghostly figure above and to the right. He may be the son of the dead man. Behind the bed and its corpse we see the head and upper body of a gowned woman wearing a scarf over her head. Her left arm is extended at 45 degrees. Her mouth may be slightly open, and she also looks up and to the right at the ghost with an expression of fear or surprise. She may be the wife or daughter of the dead man. Behind her and to the right are two small figures, probably children or grandchildren of the dead man. Of the child closest to the woman we see only the face, which is in right profile. The child farthest to the right in this group is probably a male with curly hair. We see only his face and upper chest. He is probably looking up and to the right at the ghost.

component.illusobjdesc: We see the corner of a featureless chamber or cell, perhaps with stone walls and a wooden floor.
The only piece of furniture in the room is a bed or bier, probably made of wood.
The group of figures in the design may be a family—a dead father on the bed, his wife, and three children.

A body—very probably dead—lies supine and rigid on the bed, legs together and at least the right arm at his side. The fingers of his right hand are long and prominent. This gowned figure is very probably an old man, as indicated by his long beard. His face is hidden by another figure.

At the feet of the body on the bed or bier, rising into the air at a 45 degree angle from lower right to upper left, is another gowned and bearded old man. We can see the supine figure's feet through the lower leg of the rising figure, and thus the latter is almost certainly the ghost or spirit of the dead man. His hair is long, and he faces to the left. His right arm is bent at the elbow with the forearm raised horizontally across his body. The index finger of his right hand is extended and points to the right. His left arm is bent at the elbow with the forearm raised vertically. One finger of his left hand points upward.

In the foreground on the left is a young man with curly hair. He squats or sits on his left leg, bent under his body; his right leg is extended to the right and bent slightly at the knee. He may be wearing tights, or at least a belt around his waist. His right arm is at his side, with the fingers of his right hand spread apart. His mouth is slightly open, and he appears to be looking up and to the right in fear or surprise at the ghostly figure above and to the right. He may be the son of the dead man.

Behind the bed and its corpse we see the head and upper body of a gowned woman wearing a scarf over her head. Her left arm is raised at 45 degrees. Her mouth may be slightly open, and she looks up and to the right at the ghost with an expression of fear or surprise. She may be the wife or daughter of the dead man.

Behind the prominent female figure and to the right are two small figures, probably children or grandchildren of the dead man. Of the child closest to the woman we see only the face, which is in right profile. The child farthest to the right in this group is probably a male with curly hair. We see only his face and upper chest. He is probably looking up and to the right at the ghost.

lg.l: 13Fear or Hope are  VisionIn the second state of this plate, the word "or" is changed to an ampersand.

illustration.illusobjdesc: A male traveler strides boldly to the right. He wears a coat, breeches, shoes, and a hat; he holds a walking-stick in his right hand. His right arm is bent at the elbow, with his forearm raised horizontally. His hair would appear to be long. A long shadow extends from his left foot; another may form the dark triangle lower right. The ground beneath his feet may be covered with grass; leafy trees or large plants form the background. A few clouds fill the sky above.

component.illusobjdesc: A male traveler strides boldly to the right. He wears a coat, breeches, shoes, and a hat; he holds a walking-stick in his right hand. His right arm is bent at the elbow, with his forearm raised horizontally. His hair would appear to be long.
The ground beneath the walking man's feet may be covered with grass; leafy trees or large plants form the background.
A long shadow extends from the figure's left foot; another may form the dark triangle lower right.
A few clouds fill the sky above the trees.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The entire image is filled with a door in a building, wall, or tomb. The posts and lintel of this structure are made of stone; the partly-opened door into the dark chamber is made of wood. Into this doorway steps an old man leaning on a single crutch under his left arm. He apparently holds the crutch with his left hand. His beard is long; his long hair streams out to the left, the direction in which he is facing, as though shaped by a wind blowing from right to left and into the tomb or chamber. His left foot is on tiptoe; his right foot and leg are not pictured beneath his long gown. Given the caption, the man is entering his tomb and thus dying.

component.illusobjdesc: The entire image is filled with a door in a building, wall, or tomb. The posts and lintel of this structure are made of stone; the partly-opened door into the dark chamber is made of wood.

An old man leaning on a single crutch under his left arm steps into a doorway. He apparently holds the crutch with his left hand. His beard is long; his long hair streams out to the left, the direction in which he is facing, as though shaped by a wind blowing from right to left and into the tomb or chamber. His left foot is on tiptoe; his right foot and leg are not pictured beneath his long gown. Given the caption, the man is entering his tomb and thus dying.

illustration.illusobjdesc: A gowned figure of uncertain gender squats or sits, with legs drawn up and prominent knees, upon the earth. The figure, who faces forward, has a scarf or hood over the head. Arms at side, the figure holds a slender staff in the right hand. The left hand is on the ground. The figure appears to be looking, with open eyes, directly at the viewer. A worm lies on the ground, encircling the figure and reaching upward in a loop on the right side of the figure. Further to the lower right are two or three heads partly buried in the earth. These may be severed heads, or they may be the heads of corpses whose bodies are buried in graves below the seated figure. The front-most figure, probably male, has his eyes closed. The dark background is filled with the leafless limbs, trunks, and perhaps roots of trees. There may also be a small plant, lower left, large stones (particularly on the left), and a cave behind and above the seated figure.

component.illusobjdesc: A gowned figure of uncertain gender squats or sits, with legs drawn up and prominent knees, upon the earth. The figure, who faces forward, has a scarf or hood over the head. Arms at side, the figure holds a slender staff in the right hand. The left hand is on the ground. The figure appears to be looking, with open eyes, directly at the viewer.
A worm lies on the ground, encircling the seated figure and reaching upward in a loop on the right side of the figure.

In the lower right corner of the image are two or three heads partly buried in the earth. These may be severed heads, or the heads of corpses whose bodies are buried in graves below the seated figure. The front-most figure, probably male, has his eyes closed.
The dark background is filled with the leafless limbs, trunks, and perhaps roots of trees. There may be a small plant growing in the lower left corner of the image.
The background of the image may include large stones, particularly on the right, and a cave behind and above the seated figure.

lg.l: I have said to the Worm, Thou
